National Sentence Text: Minimum specified values of the loads described in Sentence 4.1.2.1.(1), as set forth in Subsections 4.1.4. to Subsection 4.1.8., shall be increased to account for dynamic effects where applicable.
P/T Sentence Text: Minimum specified values of the loads described in Sentence 4.1.2.1.(1), as set forth in Subsections 4. to part 4., shall be increased to account for dynamic effects where applicable.

National Sentence Text: For the purpose of determining specified loads S, W or E in Subsections 4.1.6., 4.1.7.and 4.1.8., buildings shall be assigned an Importance Category based on intended use and occupancy, in accordance with Table 4.1.2.1.(See Note A-4.1.2.1.(3).) (See Note A-4.1.2.1.(3).)
P/T Sentence Text: For the purpose of determining specified loads S, W or E in Subsections 4., 4. and 4., buildings shall be assigned an Importance Category based on intended use and occupancy, in accordance with Table 4.1.2.1. (See Note A-4.1.2.1.(3).)

National Sentence Text: Where a building or structural member can be expected to be subjected to loads, forces or other effects not listed in Article 4.1.2.1., such effects shall be taken into account in the design based on the most appropriate information available. (See Note A-4.1.3.)
P/T Sentence Text: Where a building or structural member can be expected to be subjected to loads, forces or other effects not listed in Article 4.1.2.1., such effects shall be taken into account in the design based on the most appropriate information available.

National Sentence Text: In this Subsection, the term limit states means those conditions of a building structure that result in the building ceasing to fulfill the function for which it was designed (those limit states concerning safety are called ultimate limit states (ULS) and include exceeding the load-carrying capacity, overturning, sliding and fracture; those limit states that restrict the intended use and occupancy of the building are called serviceability limit states (SLS) and include deflection, vibration, permanent deformation and local structural damage such as cracking; and those limit states that represent failure under repeated loading are called fatigue limit states), specified loads (C, D, E, H, L, P, S, T and means those loads defined in Article 4.1.2.1., principal load means the specified variable load or rare load that dominates in a given load combination, companion load means a specified variable load that accompanies the principal load in a given load combination, service load means a specified load used for the evaluation of a serviceability limit state, principal-load factor means a factor applied to the principal load in a load combination to account for the variability of the load and load pattern and the analysis of its effects, companion-load factor means a factor that, when applied to a companion load in the load combination, gives the probable magnitude of a companion load acting simultaneously with the factored principal load, importance factor, I, means a factor applied in Subsections 4.1.6., 4.1.7.and 4.1.8. to obtain the specified load and take into account the consequences of failure as related to the limit state and the use and occupancy of the building, factored load means the product of a specified load and its principal-load factor or companion-load factor, effects refers to forces, moments, deformations or vibrations that occur in the structure, nominal resistance, R, of a member, connection or structure, is based on the geometry and on the specified properties of the structural materials, resistance factor,  , means a factor applied to a specified material property or to the resistance of a member, connection or structure, and that, for the limit state under consideration, takes into account the variability of dimensions and material properties, workmanship, type of failure and uncertainty in the prediction of resistance, and factored resistance,  R, means the product of nominal resistance and the applicable resistance factor.
P/T Sentence Text: In this Subsection, the term limit states means those conditions of a building structure that result in the building ceasing to fulfill the function for which it was designed (those limit states concerning safety are called ultimate limit states (ULS) and include exceeding the load-carrying capacity, overturning, sliding and fracture; those limit states that restrict the intended use and occupancy of the building are called serviceability limit states (SLS) and include deflection, vibration, permanent deformation and local structural damage such as cracking; and those limit states that represent failure under repeated loading are called fatigue limit states), specified loads (C, D, E, H, L, P, S, T and means those loads defined in Article 4.1.2.1., principal load means the specified variable load or rare load that dominates in a given load combination, companion load means a specified variable load that accompanies the principal load in a given load combination, service load means a specified load used for the evaluation of a serviceability limit state, principal-load factor means a factor applied to the principal load in a load combination to account for the variability of the load and load pattern and the analysis of its effects, companion-load factor means a factor that, when applied to a companion load in the load combination, gives the probable magnitude of a companion load acting simultaneously with the factored principal load, importance factor, I, means a factor applied in Subsections 4., 4. and 4. to obtain the specified load and take into account the consequences of failure as related to the limit state and the use and occupancy of the building, factored load means the product of a specified load and its principal-load factor or companion-load factor, effects refers to forces, moments, deformations or vibrations that occur in the structure, nominal resistance, R, of a member, connection or structure, is based on the geometry and on the specified properties of the structural materials, resistance factor,  , means a factor applied to a specified material property or to the resistance of a member, connection or structure, and that, for the limit state under consideration, takes into account the variability of dimensions and material properties, workmanship, type of failure and uncertainty in the prediction of resistance, and factored resistance,  R, means the product of nominal resistance and the applicable resistance factor.

National Sentence Text: A building and its structural components shall be designed to have sufficient strength and stability so that the factored resistance,  R, is greater than or equal to the effect of factored loads, which shall be determined in accordance with Sentence 4.1.3.2.(2).
P/T Sentence Text: A building and its structural components shall be designed to have sufficient strength and stability so that the factored resistance,  R, is greater than or equal to the effect of factored loads, which shall be determined in accordance with Sentence 4.1.3.2.(2).

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.3.2.(3), the effect of factored loads for a building or structural component shall be determined in accordance with the requirements of this Article and the following load combination cases, the applicable combination being that which results in the most critical effect: for load cases without crane loads, the load combinations listed in Table 4.1.3.2.-A, and for load cases with crane loads, the load combinations listed in Table 4.1.3.2.-B. (See Note A-4.1.3.2.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.3.2.(3), the effect of factored loads for a building or structural component shall be determined in accordance with the requirements of this Article and the following load combination cases, the applicable combination being that which results in the most critical effect: for load cases without crane loads, the load combinations listed in Table 4.1.3.2.-A, and for load cases with crane loads, the load combinations listed in Table 4.1.3.2.-B.

National Sentence Text: Other load combinations that must also be considered are the principal loads acting with the companion loads taken as zero.
P/T Sentence Text: Other load combinations that must also be considered are the principal loads acting with the companion loads taken as zero.

National Sentence Text: Where the effects due to lateral earth pressure, H, restraint effects from pre-stress, P, and imposed deformation, T, affect the structural safety, they shall be taken into account in the calculations, with load factors of 1.5, 1.0 and 1.25 assigned to H, P and T respectively. (See Note A-4.1.3.2.(4).)
P/T Sentence Text: Where the effects due to lateral earth pressure, H, restraint effects from pre-stress, P, and imposed deformation, T, affect the structural safety, they shall be taken into account in the calculations, with load factors of 1.5, 1.0 and 1.25 assigned to H, P and T respectively. (See Note A-4.1.3.2.(4).)

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.8.16.(2), the counteracting factored dead load—0.9D in load combination cases 2, 3 and 4 and 1.0D in load combination case 5 in Table 4.1.3.2.-A, and 0.9D in load combination cases 1 to 5 and 1.0D in load combination case 6 in Table 4.1.3.2.-B—shall be used when the dead load acts to resist overturning, uplift, sliding, failure due to stress reversal, and to determine anchorage requirements and the factored resistance of members. (See Note A-4.1.3.2.(5).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.8.16.(2), the counteracting factored dead load—0.9D in load combination cases 2, 3 and 4 and 1.0D in load combination case 5 in Table 4.1.3.2.-A, and 0.9D in load combination cases 1 to 5 and 1.0D in load combination case 6 in Table 4.1.3.2.-B—shall be used when the dead load acts to resist overturning, uplift, sliding, failure due to stress reversal, and to determine anchorage requirements and the factored resistance of members. (See Note A-4.1.3.2.(5).)

National Sentence Text: The principal-load factor 1.5 for live loadsL in Table 4.1.3.2.-A and LXC in Table 4.1.3.2.-B may be reduced to 1.25 for liquids in tanks.
P/T Sentence Text: The principal-load factor 1.5 for live loads L in Table 4.1.3.2.-A and LXC in Table 4.1.3.2.-B may be reduced to 1.25 for liquids in tanks.

National Sentence Text: The companion-load factor for live loadsL in Table 4.1.3.2.-A and LXC in Table 4.1.3.2.-B shall be increased by 0.5 for storage areas, and equipment areas and service rooms referred to in Table 4.1.5.3.
P/T Sentence Text: The companion-load factor for live loads L in Table 4.1.3.2.-A and LXC in Table 4.1.3.2.-B shall be increased by 0.5 for storage areas, and equipment areas and service rooms referred to in Table 4.1.5.3.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.3.2.(9), the load factor 1.25 for dead load, D, for soil, superimposed earth, plants and trees given in Tables 4.1.3.2.-Aand 4.1.3.2.-B shall be increased to 1.5, except that when the soil depth exceeds 1.2 m, the factor may be reduced to 1 + 0.6/hs but not less than 1.25, where hs is the depth of soil in metres supported by the structure.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.3.2.(9), the load factor 1.25 for dead load, D, for soil, superimposed earth, plants and trees given in Tables 4.1.3.2.-A and 4.1.3.2.-B shall be increased to 1.5, except that when the soil depth exceeds 1.2 m, the factor may be reduced to 1 + 0.6/hs but not less than 1.25, where hs is the depth of soil in metres supported by the structure.

National Sentence Text: A principal-load factor of 1.5 shall be applied to the weight of saturated soil used in load combination case 1 of Table 4.1.3.2.-A.
P/T Sentence Text: A principal-load factor of 1.5 shall be applied to the weight of saturated soil used in load combination case 1 of Table 4.1.3.2.-A.

National Sentence Text: Earthquake load, E, in load combination cases 5 of Table 4.1.3.2.-A and 6 of Table 4.1.3.2.-B includes horizontal earth pressure due to earthquake determined in accordance with Sentence 4.1.8.16.(7).
P/T Sentence Text: Earthquake load, E, in load combination cases 5 of Table 4.1.3.2.-A and 6 of Table 4.1.3.2.-B includes horizontal earth pressure due to earthquake determined in accordance with Sentence 4.1.8.16.(7).

National Sentence Text: Provision shall be made to ensure adequate stability of the structure as a whole and adequate lateral, torsional and local stability of all structural parts.
P/T Sentence Text: Provision shall be made to ensure adequate stability of the structure as a whole and adequate lateral, torsional and local stability of all structural parts.

National Sentence Text: Sway effects produced by vertical loads acting on the structure in its displaced configuration shall be taken into account in the design of buildings and their structural members.
P/T Sentence Text: Sway effects produced by vertical loads acting on the structure in its displaced configuration shall be taken into account in the design of buildings and their structural members.

National Sentence Text: A building and its structural components, including connections, shall be checked for fatigue failure under the effect of cyclical loads, as required in the standards listed in Section 4.3. (See Note A-4.1.3.3.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: A building and its structural components, including connections, shall be checked for fatigue failure under the effect of cyclical loads, as required in the standards listed in part 4. (See Note A-4.1.3.3.(1).)

National Sentence Text: Where vibration effects, such as resonance and fatigue resulting from machinery and equipment, are likely to be significant, a dynamic analysis shall be carried out. (See Note A-4.1.3.3.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: Where vibration effects, such as resonance and fatigue resulting from machinery and equipment, are likely to be significant, a dynamic analysis shall be carried out. (See Note A-4.1.3.3.(2).)

National Sentence Text: A building and its structural components shall be checked for serviceability limit states as defined in Clause 4.1.3.1.(1)(a) under the effect of service loads for serviceability criteria specified or recommended in Articles 4.1.3.5.and 4.1.3.6. and in the standards listed in Section 4.3. (See Note A-4.1.3.4.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: A building and its structural components shall be checked for serviceability limit states as defined in Sentence 4.1.3.1.(1) under the effect of service loads for serviceability criteria specified or recommended in Articles 4.1.3.5.and 4.1.3.6. and in the standards listed in part 4. (See Note A-4.1.3.4.(1).)

National Sentence Text: In proportioning structural members to limit serviceability problems resulting from deflections, consideration shall be given to the intended use of the building or member, limiting damage to non-structural members made of materials whose physical properties are known at the time of design, limiting damage to the structure itself, and creep, shrinkage, temperature changes and pre-stress. (See Note A-4.1.3.5.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: In proportioning structural members to limit serviceability problems resulting from deflections, consideration shall be given to the intended use of the building or member, limiting damage to non-structural members made of materials whose physical properties are known at the time of design, limiting damage to the structure itself, and creep, shrinkage, temperature changes and pre-stress.

National Sentence Text: The lateral deflection of buildings due to service wind and gravity loads shall be checked to ensure that structural elements and non-structural elements whose nature is known at the time the structural design is carried out will not be damaged.
P/T Sentence Text: The lateral deflection of buildings due to service wind and gravity loads shall be checked to ensure that structural elements and non-structural elements whose nature is known at the time the structural design is carried out will not be damaged.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.3.5.(4), the total drift per storey under service wind and gravity loads shall not exceed 1/500 of the storey height unless other drift limits are specified in the design standards referenced in Section 4.3. (See Note A-4.1.3.5.(3).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.3.5.(4), the total drift per storey under service wind and gravity loads shall not exceed 1/500 of the storey height unless other drift limits are specified in the design standards referenced in part 4. (See Note A-4.1.3.5.(3).)

National Sentence Text: The deflection limits required in Sentence 4.1.3.5.(3) do not apply to industrial buildings or sheds if experience has proven that greater movement will have no significant adverse effects on the strength and function of the building.
P/T Sentence Text: The deflection limits required in Sentence 4.1.3.5.(3) do not apply to industrial buildings or sheds if experience has proven that greater movement will have no significant adverse effects on the strength and function of the building.

National Sentence Text: The building structure shall be designed for lateral deflection due to E, in accordance with Article 4.1.8.13.
P/T Sentence Text: The building structure shall be designed for lateral deflection due to E, in accordance with Article 4.1.8.13.

National Sentence Text: Floor systems susceptible to vibration shall be designed so that vibrations will have no significant adverse effects on the intended occupancy of the building. (See Note A-4.1.3.6.(1).) (See Note A-4.1.3.6.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: Floor systems susceptible to vibration shall be designed so that vibrations will have no significant adverse effects on the intended occupancy of the building. (See Note A-4.1.3.6.(1).)

National Sentence Text: Where the fundamental vibration frequency of a structural system supporting an assembly occupancy used for rhythmic activities, such as dancing, concerts, jumping exercises or gymnastics, is less than 6 Hz, the effects of resonance shall be investigated by means of a dynamic analysis. (See Note A-4.1.3.6.(2).) Note A-4.1.3.6.(2)
P/T Sentence Text: Where the fundamental vibration frequency of a structural system supporting an assembly occupancy used for rhythmic activities, such as dancing, concerts, jumping exercises or gymnastics, is less than 6 Hz, the effects of resonance shall be investigated by means of a dynamic analysis. (See Note A-4.1.3.6.(2) .)

National Sentence Text: A building susceptible to lateral vibration under wind load shall be designed in accordance with Article 4.1.7.1. so that the vibrations will have no significant adverse effects on the intended use and occupancy of the building. (See Note A-4.1.3.6.(3).)
P/T Sentence Text: A building susceptible to lateral vibration under wind load shall be designed in accordance with Article 4.1.7.1. so that the vibrations will have no significant adverse effects on the intended use and occupancy of the building. (See Note A-4.1.3.6.(3).)

National Sentence Text: The specified dead load for a structural member consists of the weight of the member itself, the weight of all materials of construction incorporated into the building to be supported permanently by the member, the weight of partitions, the weight of permanent equipment, and the vertical load due to earth, plants and trees.
P/T Sentence Text: The specified dead load for a structural member consists of the weight of the member itself, the weight of all materials of construction incorporated into the building to be supported permanently by the member, the weight of partitions, the weight of permanent equipment, and the vertical load due to earth, plants and trees.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.4.1.(5), in areas of a building where partitions, other than permanent partitions, are shown on the drawings, or where partitions might be added in the future, allowance shall be made for the weight of such partitions.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.4.1.(5), in areas of a building where partitions, other than permanent partitions, are shown on the drawings, or where partitions might be added in the future, allowance shall be made for the weight of such partitions.

National Sentence Text: The partition weight allowance referred to in Sentence 4.1.4.1.(2) shall be determined from the actual or anticipated weight of the partitions placed in any probable position, but shall be not less than 1 kPa over the area of floor being considered.
P/T Sentence Text: The partition weight allowance referred to in Sentence 4.1.4.1.(2) shall be determined from the actual or anticipated weight of the partitions placed in any probable position, but shall be not less than 1 kPa over the area of floor being considered.

National Sentence Text: Partition loads used in design shall be shown on the drawings as provided in Clause 2.2.4.3.(1)(d).
P/T Sentence Text: Partition loads used in design shall be shown on the drawings as provided in Clause 2.2.4.3.(1).

National Sentence Text: In cases where the dead load of the partition is counteractive, the load allowances referred to in Sentences 4.1.4.1.(2)and 4.1.4.1.(3) shall not be included in the design calculations.
P/T Sentence Text: In cases where the dead load of the partition is counteractive, the load allowances referred to in Sentences 4.1.4.1.(2) and 4.1.4.1.(3) shall not be included in the design calculations.

National Sentence Text: Except for structures where the dead load of soil is part of the load-resisting system, where the dead load due to soil, superimposed earth, plants and trees is counteractive, it shall not be included in the design calculations. (See Note A-4.1.4.1.(6).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except for structures where the dead load of soil is part of the load-resisting system, where the dead load due to soil, superimposed earth, plants and trees is counteractive, it shall not be included in the design calculations. (See Note A-4.1.4.1.(6).)

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.5.1.(2), the specified live load on an area of floor or roof depends on the intended use and occupancy, and shall not be less than either the uniformly distributed load patterns listed in Article 4.1.5.3., the loads due to the intended use and occupancy, or the concentrated loads listed in Article 4.1.5.9., whichever produces the most critical effect. (See Note A-4.1.5.1.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.5.1.(2), the specified live load on an area of floor or roof depends on the intended use and occupancy, and shall not be less than either the uniformly distributed load patterns listed in Article 4.1.5.3., the loads due to the intended use and occupancy, or the concentrated loads listed in Article 4.1.5.9., whichever produces the most critical effect. (See Note A-4.1.5.1.(1).)

National Sentence Text: For buildings in the Low Importance Category as described in Table 4.1.2.1., a factor of 0.8 may be applied to the live load.
P/T Sentence Text: For buildings in the Low Importance Category as described in Table 4.1.2.1., a factor of 0.8 may be applied to the live load.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.5.2.(2), where the use of an area of floor or roof is not provided for in Article 4.1.5.3., the specified live loads due to the use and occupancy of the area shall be determined from an analysis of the loads resulting from the weight of the probable assembly of persons, the probable accumulation of equipment and furnishings, and the probable storage of materials.

National Sentence Text: For buildings in the Low Importance Category as described in Table 4.1.2.1., a factor of 0.8 may be applied to the live load.
P/T Sentence Text: For buildings in the Low Importance Category as described in Table 4.1.2.1., a factor of 0.8 may be applied to the live load.

National Sentence Text: The uniformly distributed live load shall be not less than the value listed in Table 4.1.5.3., which may be reduced as provided in Article 4.1.5.8., applied uniformly over the entire area or on any portions of the area, whichever produces the most critical effects in the members concerned.
P/T Sentence Text: The uniformly distributed live load shall be not less than the value listed in Table 4.1.5.3., which may be reduced as provided in Article 4.1.5.8., applied uniformly over the entire area or on any portions of the area, whichever produces the most critical effects in the members concerned.

National Sentence Text: The following shall be designed to carry not less than the specified load required for the occupancy they serve, provided they cannot be used by an assembly of people as a viewing area: corridors, lobbies and aisles not more than 1 200 mm wide, all corridors above the first storey of residential areas of apartments, hotels and motels, and interior balconies and mezzanines. (See Note A-4.1.5.5.)
P/T Sentence Text: The following shall be designed to carry not less than the specified load required for the occupancy they serve, provided they cannot be used by an assembly of people as a viewing area: corridors, lobbies and aisles not more than 1 200 mm wide, all corridors above the first storey of residential areas of apartments, hotels and motels, and interior balconies and mezzanines.

National Sentence Text: Exterior areas accessible to vehicular traffic shall be designed for their intended use, including the weight of firefighting equipment, but not for less than the snow and rain loads prescribed in Subsection 4.1.6.
P/T Sentence Text: Exterior areas accessible to vehicular traffic shall be designed for their intended use, including the weight of firefighting equipment, but not for less than the snow and rain loads prescribed in part 4.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 4.1.5.5.(3)and 4.1.5.5.(4), roofs shall be designed for either the uniform live loads specified in Table 4.1.5.3., the concentrated live loads listed in Table 4.1.5.9., or the snow and rain loads prescribed in Subsection 4.1.6., whichever produces the most critical effects in the members concerned.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 4.1.5.5.(3) and 4.1.5.5.(4), roofs shall be designed for either the uniform live loads specified in Table 4.1.5.3., the concentrated live loads listed in Table 4.1.5.9., or the snow and rain loads prescribed in part 4., whichever produces the most critical effects in the members concerned.

National Sentence Text: Exterior areas accessible to pedestrian traffic, but not vehicular traffic, shall be designed for their intended use, but not for less than the greater of the live load prescribed for assembly areas in Table 4.1.5.3., or the snow and rain loads prescribed in Subsection 4.1.6.
P/T Sentence Text: Exterior areas accessible to pedestrian traffic, but not vehicular traffic, shall be designed for their intended use, but not for less than the greater of the live load prescribed for assembly areas in Table 4.1.5.3., or the snow and rain loads prescribed in part 4.

National Sentence Text: Roof parking decks shall be designed for either the uniformly distributed live loads specified in Table 4.1.5.3., the concentrated live loads listed in Table 4.1.5.9., or the roof snow load, whichever produces the most critical effect in the members concerned.
P/T Sentence Text: Roof parking decks shall be designed for either the uniformly distributed live loads specified in Table 4.1.5.3., the concentrated live loads listed in Table 4.1.5.9., or the roof snow load, whichever produces the most critical effect in the members concerned.

National Sentence Text: The minimum specified live load listed in Table 4.1.5.3. for dining areas may be reduced to 2.4 kPa for areas in buildings that are being converted to dining areas, provided that the floor area does not exceed 100 m2 and the dining area will not be used for other assembly purposes, including dancing.
P/T Sentence Text: The minimum specified live load listed in Table 4.1.5.3. for dining areas may be reduced to 2.4 kPa for areas in buildings that are being converted to dining areas, provided that the floor area does not exceed 100 m2 and the dining area will not be used for other assembly purposes, including dancing.

National Sentence Text: Where an area of floor or roof is intended for 2 or more occupancies at different times, the value to be used from Table 4.1.5.3. shall be the greatest value for any of the occupancies concerned. (See Note A-4.1.5.8.)
P/T Sentence Text: Where an area of floor or roof is intended for 2 or more occupancies at different times, the value to be used from Table 4.1.5.3. shall be the greatest value for any of the occupancies concerned.

National Sentence Text: An area used for assembly occupancies designed for a live load of less than 4.8 kPa and roofs designed for the minimum loading specified in Table 4.1.5.3. shall have no reduction for tributary area.
P/T Sentence Text: An area used for assembly occupancies designed for a live load of less than 4.8 kPa and roofs designed for the minimum loading specified in Table 4.1.5.3. shall have no reduction for tributary area.

National Sentence Text: Where a structural member supports a tributary area of a floor or a roof, or a combination thereof, that is greater than 80 m2 and either used for assembly occupancies designed for a live load of 4.8 kPa or more, or used for storage, manufacturing, retail stores, garages or as a footbridge, the specified live load due to use and occupancy is the load specified in Article 4.1.5.3. multiplied by 0.5+20/Awhere A is the tributary area in square metres for this type of use and occupancy.
P/T Sentence Text: Where a structural member supports a tributary area of a floor or a roof, or a combination thereof, that is greater than 80 m2 and either used for assembly occupancies designed for a live load of 4.8 kPa or more, or used for storage, manufacturing, retail stores, garages or as a footbridge, the specified live load due to use and occupancy is the load specified in Article 4.1.5.3. multiplied by 0.5+20/Awhere A is the tributary area in square metres for this type of use and occupancy.

National Sentence Text: Where a structural member supports a tributary area of a floor or a roof, or a combination thereof, that is greater than 20 m2 and used for any use or occupancy other than those indicated in Sentences 4.1.5.8.(1)and 4.1.5.8.(2), the specified live load due to use and occupancy is the load specified in Article 4.1.5.3. multiplied by 0.3+9.8/Bwhere B is the tributary area in square metres for this type of use and occupancy.
P/T Sentence Text: Where a structural member supports a tributary area of a floor or a roof, or a combination thereof, that is greater than 20 m2 and used for any use or occupancy other than those indicated in Sentences 4.1.5.8.(1) and 4.1.5.8.(2), the specified live load due to use and occupancy is the load specified in Article 4.1.5.3. multiplied by 0.3+9.8/Bwhere B is the tributary area in square metres for this type of use and occupancy.

National Sentence Text: Where the specified live load for a floor is reduced in accordance with Sentence 4.1.5.8.(2)or 4.1.5.8.(3), the structural drawings shall indicate that a live load reduction factor for tributary area has been applied.
P/T Sentence Text: Where the specified live load for a floor is reduced in accordance with Sentence 4.1.5.8.(2) or 4.1.5.8.(3), the structural drawings shall indicate that a live load reduction factor for tributary area has been applied.

National Sentence Text: The specified live load due to possible concentrations of load resulting from the use of an area of floor or roof shall not be less than that listed in Table 4.1.5.9. applied over the loaded area noted and located so as to cause maximum effects, except that for occupancies not listed in Table 4.1.5.9., the concentrations of load shall be determined in accordance with Article 4.1.5.2.
P/T Sentence Text: The specified live load due to possible concentrations of load resulting from the use of an area of floor or roof shall not be less than that listed in Table 4.1.5.9. applied over the loaded area noted and located so as to cause maximum effects, except that for occupancies not listed in Table 4.1.5.9., the concentrations of load shall be determined in accordance with Article 4.1.5.2.

National Sentence Text: The floor assembly and other structural elements that support fixed seats in any building used for assembly occupancies accommodating large numbers of people at one time, such as grandstands, stadia and theatre balconies, shall be designed to resist a horizontal force equal to not less than 0.3 kN for each metre length of seats acting parallel to each row of seats, and not less than 0.15 kN for each metre length of seats acting at right angles to each row of seats, based on the assumption that these forces are acting independently of each other. (See Note A-4.1.5.11.)
P/T Sentence Text: The floor assembly and other structural elements that support fixed seats in any building used for assembly occupancies accommodating large numbers of people at one time, such as grandstands, stadia and theatre balconies, shall be designed to resist a horizontal force equal to not less than 0.3 kN for each metre length of seats acting parallel to each row of seats, and not less than 0.15 kN for each metre length of seats acting at right angles to each row of seats, based on the assumption that these forces are acting independently of each other.

National Sentence Text: The minimum specified load due to equipment, machinery or other objects that may produce impact shall be the sum of the weight of the equipment or machinery and its maximum lifting capacity, multiplied by an appropriate factor listed in Table 4.1.5.11.
P/T Sentence Text: The minimum specified load due to equipment, machinery or other objects that may produce impact shall be the sum of the weight of the equipment or machinery and its maximum lifting capacity, multiplied by an appropriate factor listed in Table 4.1.5.11.

National Sentence Text: Crane-supporting structures shall be designed for the appropriate load combinations listed in Article 4.1.3.2.
P/T Sentence Text: Crane-supporting structures shall be designed for the appropriate load combinations listed in Article 4.1.3.2.

National Sentence Text: Crane runway structures shall be designed to resist a horizontal force applied normal to the top of the rails equal to not less than 20% of the sum of the weights of the lifted load and the crane trolley (excluding other parts of the crane).
P/T Sentence Text: Crane runway structures shall be designed to resist a horizontal force applied normal to the top of the rails equal to not less than 20% of the sum of the weights of the lifted load and the crane trolley (excluding other parts of the crane).

National Sentence Text: The force described in Sentence 4.1.5.11.(3) shall be equally distributed on each side of the runway and shall be assumed to act in either direction.
P/T Sentence Text: The force described in Sentence 4.1.5.11.(3) shall be equally distributed on each side of the runway and shall be assumed to act in either direction.

National Sentence Text: Crane runway structures shall be designed to resist a horizontal force applied parallel to the top of the rails equal to not less than 10% of the maximum wheel loads of the crane.
P/T Sentence Text: Crane runway structures shall be designed to resist a horizontal force applied parallel to the top of the rails equal to not less than 10% of the maximum wheel loads of the crane.

National Sentence Text: Bleacher seats shall be designed for a uniformly distributed live load of 1.75 kN for each linear metre or for a concentrated load of 2.2 kN distributed over a length of 0.75 m, whichever produces the most critical effect on the supporting members.
P/T Sentence Text: Bleacher seats shall be designed for a uniformly distributed live load of 1.75 kN for each linear metre or for a concentrated load of 2.2 kN distributed over a length of 0.75 m, whichever produces the most critical effect on the supporting members.

National Sentence Text: Bleachers shall be checked by the erector after erection to ensure that all structural members, including bracing specified in the design, have been installed.
P/T Sentence Text: Bleachers shall be checked by the erector after erection to ensure that all structural members, including bracing specified in the design, have been installed.

National Sentence Text: Telescopic bleachers shall be provided with locking devices to ensure stability while in use.
P/T Sentence Text: Telescopic bleachers shall be provided with locking devices to ensure stability while in use.

National Sentence Text: Helicopter landing areas on roofs shall be constructed in conformance with the requirements for heliports contained in TC SOR/96-433 Canadian Aviation Regulations – Part III (See Note A-4.1.5.14. and 4.1.5.15.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: Helicopter landing areas on roofs shall be constructed in conformance with the requirements for heliports contained in TC SOR/96-433 Canadian Aviation Regulations – Part III

National Sentence Text: The minimum specified horizontal load applied outward at the minimum required height of every required guard shall be 3.0 kN/m for open viewing stands without fixed seats and for means of egress in grandstands, stadia, bleachers and arenas, a concentrated load of 1.0 kN applied at any point, so as to produce the most critical effect, for access ways to equipment platforms, contiguous stairs and similar areas where the gathering of many people is improbable, and 0.75 kN/m or a concentrated load of 1.0 kN applied at any point so as to produce the most critical effect, whichever governs for locations other than those described in Clauses 4.1.5.14.(1)(a)and 4.1.5.14.(1)(b).

National Sentence Text: The minimum specified horizontal load applied inward at the minimum required height of every required guard shall be half that specified in Sentence 4.1.5.14.(1).
P/T Sentence Text: The minimum specified horizontal load applied inward at the minimum required height of every required guard shall be half that specified in Sentence 4.1.5.14.(1).

National Sentence Text: Individual elements within the guard, including solid panels and pickets, shall be designed for a load of 0.5 kN applied outward over an area of 100 mm by 100 mm located at any point in the element or elements so as to produce the most critical effect.
P/T Sentence Text: Individual elements within the guard, including solid panels and pickets, shall be designed for a load of 0.5 kN applied outward over an area of 100 mm by 100 mm located at any point in the element or elements so as to produce the most critical effect.

National Sentence Text: The size of the opening between any two adjacent vertical elements within a guard shall not exceed the limits required by Part 3 when each of these elements is subjected to a specified live load of 0.1 kN applied in opposite directions in the in-plane direction of the guard so as to produce the most critical effect.
P/T Sentence Text: The size of the opening between any two adjacent vertical elements within a guard shall not exceed the limits required by part 3. when each of these elements is subjected to a specified live load of 0.1 kN applied in opposite directions in the in-plane direction of the guard so as to produce the most critical effect.

National Sentence Text: The loads required in Sentence 4.1.5.14.(3) need not be considered to act simultaneously with the loads provided for in Sentences 4.1.5.14.(1), 4.1.5.14.(2)and 4.1.5.14.(6).
P/T Sentence Text: The loads required in Sentence 4.1.5.14.(3) need not be considered to act simultaneously with the loads provided for in Sentences 4.1.5.14.(1) , 4.1.5.14.(2) and 4.1.5.14.(6).

National Sentence Text: The minimum specified load applied vertically at the top of every required guard shall be 1.5 kN/m and need not be considered to act simultaneously with the horizontal load provided for in Sentence 4.1.5.14.(1).

National Sentence Text: Handrails and their supports shall be designed and constructed to withstand the following loads, which need not be considered to act simultaneously: a concentrated load not less than 0.9 kN applied at any point and in any direction for all handrails, and a uniform load not less than 0.7 kN/m applied in any direction to handrails not located within dwelling units.
P/T Sentence Text: Handrails and their supports shall be designed and constructed to withstand the following loads, which need not be considered to act simultaneously: a concentrated load not less than 0.9 kN applied at any point and in any direction for all handrails, and a uniform load not less than 0.7 kN/m applied in any direction to handrails not located within dwelling units.

National Sentence Text: Vehicle guardrails shall be designed for a concentrated load of 22 kN applied horizontally outward at any point 500 mm above the floor surface so as to produce the most critical effect. (See Note A-4.1.5.14. and 4.1.5.15.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: Vehicle guardrails shall be designed for a concentrated load of 22 kN applied horizontally outward at any point 500 mm above the floor surface so as to produce the most critical effect. (See Note A-4.1.5.14..)

P/T Sentence Text: Where the floor elevation on one side of a wall, including a wall around a shaft, is more than 600 mm higher than the elevation of the floor or ground on the other side, the wall shall be designed to resist the appropriate outward lateral design loads prescribed elsewhere in part 4. or 0.5 kPa acting outward, whichever produces the more critical effect.

National Sentence Text: Firewalls shall be designed to resist the maximum effect due to the appropriate lateral design loads prescribed elsewhere in this Section, or a factored lateral load of 0.5 kPa under fire conditions, as described in Sentence 4.1.5.17.(2).

National Sentence Text: Under fire conditions, where the fire-resistance rating of the structure is less than that of the firewall, lateral support shall be assumed to be provided by the structure on one side only, or another structural support system capable of resisting the loads imposed by a fire on either side of the firewall shall be provided.

National Sentence Text: The specified load on a roof or any other building surface subject to snow and associated rain shall be the snow load specified in Article 4.1.6.2., or the rain load specified in Article 4.1.6.4., whichever produces the more critical effect. (See Note A-4.1.6.2.)
P/T Sentence Text: The specified load on a roof or any other building surface subject to snow and associated rain shall be the snow load specified in Article 4.1.6.2., or the rain load specified in Article 4.1.6.4., whichever produces the more critical effect.

P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided for in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(4), the wind exposure factor, Cw, shall be 1.0.

National Sentence Text: Unless otherwise stated in this Subsection, the slope factor, Cs, shall be 1.0 when used in conjunction with accumulation factors for increased snow loads.
P/T Sentence Text: Unless otherwise stated in this Subsection, the slope factor, Cs, shall be 1.0 when used in conjunction with accumulation factors for increased snow loads.

National Sentence Text: The accumulation factor, Ca, shall be 1.0, which corresponds to the uniform snow load case, except that where appropriate for the shape of the roof, it shall be assigned other values that account for increased non-uniform snow loads due to snow drifting onto a roof that is at a level lower than other parts of the same building or at a level lower than another building within 5 m of it horizontally, as prescribed in Articles 4.1.6.5., Article 4.1.6.6.and 4.1.6.8., increased non-uniform snow loads on areas adjacent to roof projections, such as penthouses, large chimneys and equipment, as prescribed in Articles 4.1.6.7.and 4.1.6.8., non-uniform snow loads on gable, arch or curved roofs and domes, as prescribed in Articles 4.1.6.9.and 4.1.6.10., increased snow or ice loads due to snow sliding as prescribed in Article 4.1.6.11., increased snow loads in roof valleys, as prescribed in Article 4.1.6.12., and increased snow or ice loads due to meltwater draining from adjacent building elements and roof projections.

National Sentence Text: For shapes not addressed in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(8), Ca corresponding to the non-uniform snow load case shall be established based on applicable field observations, special analyses including local climatic effects, appropriate model tests, or a combination of these methods.
P/T Sentence Text: For shapes not addressed in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(8), Ca corresponding to the non-uniform snow load case shall be established based on applicable field observations, special analyses including local climatic effects, appropriate model tests, or a combination of these methods.

National Sentence Text: A roof or other building surface and its structural members subject to loads due to snow accumulation shall be designed for the specified load given in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(1), distributed over the entire loaded area.
P/T Sentence Text: A roof or other building surface and its structural members subject to loads due to snow accumulation shall be designed for the specified load given in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(1), distributed over the entire loaded area.

National Sentence Text: In addition to the distribution mentioned in Sentence 4.1.6.3.(1), flat roofs and shed roofs, gable roofs of 15° slope or less, and arch or curved roofs shall be designed for the specified uniform snow load indicated in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(1), which shall be calculated using the accumulation factor Ca = 1.0, distributed on any one portion of the loaded area and half of this load on the remainder of the loaded area, in such a way as to produce the most critical effects on the member concerned. (See Note A-4.1.6.3.(2).) (See Note A-4.1.6.3.(2).)
P/T Sentence Text: In addition to the distribution mentioned in Sentence 4.1.6.3.(1), flat roofs and shed roofs, gable roofs of 15° slope or less, and arch or curved roofs shall be designed for the specified uniform snow load indicated in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(1), which shall be calculated using the accumulation factor Ca = 1.0, distributed on any one portion of the loaded area and half of this load on the remainder of the loaded area, in such a way as to produce the most critical effects on the member concerned. (See Note A-4.1.6.3.(2).)

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.6.4.(4), the specified load, S, due to the accumulation of rainwater on a surface whose position, shape and deflection under load make such an accumulation possible, is that resulting from the one-day rainfall determined in conformance with Subsection 1.1.3. and applied over the horizontal projection of the surface and all tributary surfaces. (See Note A-4.1.6.4.(1).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.6.4.(4), the specified load, S, due to the accumulation of rainwater on a surface whose position, shape and deflection under load make such an accumulation possible, is that resulting from the one-day rainfall determined in conformance with part 1. and applied over the horizontal projection of the surface and all tributary surfaces. (See Note A-4.1.6.4.(1).)

National Sentence Text: The provisions of Sentence 4.1.6.4.(1) apply whether or not the surface is provided with a means of drainage, such as rainwater leaders.
P/T Sentence Text: The provisions of Sentence 4.1.6.4.(1) apply whether or not the surface is provided with a means of drainage, such as rainwater leaders.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(1), loads due to rain need not be considered to act simultaneously with loads due to snow. (See Note A-4.1.6.4.(3).)
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.6.2.(1), loads due to rain need not be considered to act simultaneously with loads due to snow. (See Note A-4.1.6.4.(3).)

National Sentence Text: Where scuppers are provided and where the position, shape and deflection of the loaded surface make an accumulation of rainwater possible, the loads due to rain shall be the lesser of either the one-day rainfall determined in conformance with Subsection 1.1.3. or a depth of rainwater equal to 30 mm above the level of the scuppers, applied over the horizontal projection of the surface and tributary areas.
P/T Sentence Text: Where scuppers are provided and where the position, shape and deflection of the loaded surface make an accumulation of rainwater possible, the loads due to rain shall be the lesser of either the one-day rainfall determined in conformance with part 1. or a depth of rainwater equal to 30 mm above the level of the scuppers, applied over the horizontal projection of the surface and tributary areas.

National Sentence Text: The drift loads on the lower level roof against the two faces of an outside corner of an upper level roof or roof obstruction shall be extended radially around the corner as shown in Figure 4.1.6.8. and may be taken as the least severe of the drift loads lying against the two faces of the corner.

National Sentence Text: The drift loads on the lower level roof against the two faces of an inside corner of an upper level roof or a parapet shall be calculated for each face and applied as far as the bisector of the corner angle as shown in Figure 4.1.6.8.. (See Note A-4.1.6.9.)

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.6.11.(2), where an upper roof, or part thereof, slopes downwards with a slope   > 0 towards a lower roof, the snow load, S, on the lower roof, determined in accordance with Articles 4.1.6.2.and 4.1.6.5., shall be augmented in accordance with Sentence 4.1.6.11.(3) to account for the additional load resulting from sliding snow.

National Sentence Text: Sentence 4.1.6.11.(1) need not apply where snow from the upper roof is prevented from sliding by a parapet or other effective means, or the upper roof is not considered slippery and has a slope of less than 20°.
P/T Sentence Text: Sentence 4.1.6.11.(1) need not apply where snow from the upper roof is prevented from sliding by a parapet or other effective means, or the upper roof is not considered slippery and has a slope of less than 20°.

National Sentence Text: The total weight of additional snow resulting from sliding shall be taken as half the total weight of snow resulting from the uniform load case prescribed in Article 4.1.6.2. with the accumulation factor Ca = 1.0 for the relevant part of the upper roof, the slope factor, Cs, based on the slope of the lower roof, as prescribed in Sentences 4.1.6.2.(5)and 4.1.6.2.(6), and the sliding snow distributed on the lower roof such that it is a maximum for x = 0 and decreases linearly to 0 at x = xd, as shown in Figure 4.1.6.11., where x and xd are as defined in Article 4.1.6.5.

National Sentence Text: For valleys in curved or sloped roofs with a slope   > 10°, in addition to the full and partial load cases defined in Article 4.1.6.3., the non-uniform load cases II and III presented in Sentences 4.1.6.12.(2)and 4.1.6.12.(3) shall be considered to account for sliding, creeping and movement of meltwater.
P/T Sentence Text: For valleys in curved or sloped roofs with a slope   > 10°, in addition to the full and partial load cases defined in Article 4.1.6.3., the non-uniform load cases II and III presented in Sentences 4.1.6.12.(2) and 4.1.6.12.(3) shall be considered to account for sliding, creeping and movement of meltwater.

National Sentence Text: For case II (see Figure 4.1.6.12.), the accumulation factor, Ca, shall be calculated as follows: Ca=1Cb for0<x b/4,andCa=0.5Cb forb/4<x b/2wherex = horizontal distance from the bottom of the valley, and b= twice the horizontal distance between the bottom of the valley and the peak of the roof surface in question.

National Sentence Text: For the purposes of calculating snow loads in drifts, the specific weight of snow,  , shall be taken as 4.0 kN/m3 or 0.43SS + 2.2 kN/m3, whichever is lesser.
P/T Sentence Text: For the purposes of calculating snow loads in drifts, the specific weight of snow,  , shall be taken as 4.0 kN/m3 or 0.43SS + 2.2 kN/m3 , whichever is lesser.

National Sentence Text: Snow removal by mechanical, thermal, manual or other means shall not be used as a rationale to reduce design snow loads.
P/T Sentence Text: Snow removal by mechanical, thermal, manual or other means shall not be used as a rationale to reduce design snow loads.

National Sentence Text: For lattice structures connected to the building, and other building components or appurtenances involving small width elements subject to significant ice accretion, the weight of ice accretion and the effective area presented to wind shall be as prescribed in CSA S37-13 Antennas, Towers, and Antenna-Supporting Structures
P/T Sentence Text: For lattice structures connected to the building, and other building components or appurtenances involving small width elements subject to significant ice accretion, the weight of ice accretion and the effective area presented to wind shall be as prescribed in CSA S37-13 Antennas, Towers, and Antenna-Supporting Structures

National Sentence Text: The specified wind loads for a building and its components shall be determined using the Static, Dynamic or Wind Tunnel Procedure as stated in Sentences 4.1.7.1.(2)to 4.1.7.1.(5).
P/T Sentence Text: The specified wind loads for a building and its components shall be determined using the Static, Dynamic or Wind Tunnel Procedure as stated in Sentences 4.1.7.1.(2) to 4.1.7.1.(5).

National Sentence Text: For the design of buildings that are not dynamically sensitive, as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.2.(1), one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Static Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.3., the Dynamic Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.8., or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.12.
P/T Sentence Text: For the design of buildings that are not dynamically sensitive, as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.2.(1), one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Static Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.3., the Dynamic Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.8., or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.12.

National Sentence Text: For the design of buildings that are dynamically sensitive, as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.2.(2), one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Dynamic Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.8., or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.12.
P/T Sentence Text: For the design of buildings that are dynamically sensitive, as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.2.(2), one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Dynamic Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.8., or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.12.

National Sentence Text: For the design of buildings that may be subject to wake buffeting or channelling effects from nearby buildings, or that are very dynamically sensitive, as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.2.(3), the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.12., shall be used to determine the specified wind loads.
P/T Sentence Text: For the design of buildings that may be subject to wake buffeting or channelling effects from nearby buildings, or that are very dynamically sensitive, as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.2.(3), the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.12., shall be used to determine the specified wind loads.

National Sentence Text: For the design of cladding and secondary structural members, one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Static Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.3., or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.12.
P/T Sentence Text: For the design of cladding and secondary structural members, one of the following procedures shall be used to determine the specified wind loads: the Static Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.3., or the Wind Tunnel Procedure described in Article 4.1.7.12.

National Sentence Text: Computational fluid dynamics shall not be used to determine the specified wind loads for a building and its components. (See Note A-4.1.7.1.(6).) (See Note A-4.1.7.2.)
P/T Sentence Text: Computational fluid dynamics shall not be used to determine the specified wind loads for a building and its components. (See Note A-4.1.7.1.(6).)

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 4.1.7.2.(2)and 4.1.7.2.(3), a building is permitted to be classified as not dynamically sensitive.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 4.1.7.2.(2) and 4.1.7.2.(3), a building is permitted to be classified as not dynamically sensitive.

National Sentence Text: A building shall be classified as dynamically sensitive if its lowest natural frequency is less than 1 Hz and greater than 0.25 Hz, its height is greater than 60 m, or its height is greater than 4 times its minimum effective width, where the effective width, w, of a building shall be taken as w= hiwihiwhere the summations are over the height of the building for a given wind direction, hi is the height above grade to level i, and wi is the width normal to the wind direction at height hi; the minimum effective width is the lowest value of the effective width considering all wind directions.
P/T Sentence Text: A building shall be classified as dynamically sensitive if its lowest natural frequency is less than 1 Hz and greater than 0.25 Hz, its height is greater than 60 m, or its height is greater than 4 times its minimum effective width, where the effective width, w, of a building shall be taken as w= hiwihiwhere the summations are over the height of the building for a given wind direction, hi is the height above grade to level i, and wi is the width normal to the wind direction at height hi; the minimum effective width is the lowest value of the effective width considering all wind directions.

National Sentence Text: A building shall be classified as very dynamically sensitive if its lowest natural frequency is less than or equal to 0.25 Hz, or its height is more than 6 times its minimum effective width as defined in Clause 4.1.7.2.(2)(c).
P/T Sentence Text: A building shall be classified as very dynamically sensitive if its lowest natural frequency is less than or equal to 0.25 Hz, or its height is more than 6 times its minimum effective width as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.2.(2).

National Sentence Text: The specified external pressure or suction due to wind on part or all of a surface of a building shall be calculated as follows: p=IWqCeCtCgC pwhere p= specified external pressure acting statically and in a direction normal to the surface, considered positive when the pressure acts towards the surface and negative when it acts away from the surface, IW= importance factor for wind load, as provided in Table 4.1.7.3., q= reference velocity pressure, as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(4), Ce= exposure factor, as provided in Sentences 4.1.7.3.(5)and 4.1.7.3.(7), Ct= topographic factor, as provided in Article 4.1.7.4., Cg= gust effect factor, as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(8), and Cp= external pressure coefficient, as provided in Articles 4.1.7.5.and 4.1.7.6.
P/T Sentence Text: The specified external pressure or suction due to wind on part or all of a surface of a building shall be calculated as follows: p=IWqCeCtCgC pwhere p= specified external pressure acting statically and in a direction normal to the surface, considered positive when the pressure acts towards the surface and negative when it acts away from the surface, IW= importance factor for wind load, as provided in Table 4.1.7.3., q= reference velocity pressure, as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(4), Ce= exposure factor, as provided in Sentences 4.1.7.3.(5)and 4.1.7.3.(7), Ct= topographic factor, as provided in Article 4.1.7.4., Cg= gust effect factor, as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(8), and Cp= external pressure coefficient, as provided in Articles 4.1.7.5.and 4.1.7.6.

National Sentence Text: The net wind load for the building as a whole shall be the algebraic difference of the loads on the windward and leeward surfaces, and in some cases, may be calculated as the sum of the products of the external pressures or suctions and the areas of the surfaces over which they are averaged as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(1).
P/T Sentence Text: The net wind load for the building as a whole shall be the algebraic difference of the loads on the windward and leeward surfaces, and in some cases, may be calculated as the sum of the products of the external pressures or suctions and the areas of the surfaces over which they are averaged as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(1).

National Sentence Text: The net specified pressure due to wind on part or all of a surface of a building shall be the algebraic difference, such as to produce the most critical effect, of the external pressure or suction calculated in accordance with Sentence 4.1.7.3.(1) and the specified internal pressure or suction due to wind calculated as follows: pi=IWqCeiCtCgi Cpiwhere pi= specified internal pressure acting statically and in a direction normal to the surface, either as a pressure directed towards the surface or as a suction directed away from the surface, IW, q, Ct= as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(1), Cei= exposure factor for internal pressure, as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(7), Cgi= internal gust effect factor, as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(10), and Cpi= internal pressure coefficient, as provided in Article 4.1.7.7.
P/T Sentence Text: The net specified pressure due to wind on part or all of a surface of a building shall be the algebraic difference, such as to produce the most critical effect, of the external pressure or suction calculated in accordance with Sentence 4.1.7.3.(1) and the specified internal pressure or suction due to wind calculated as follows: pi=IWqCeiCtCgi Cpiwhere pi= specified internal pressure acting statically and in a direction normal to the surface, either as a pressure directed towards the surface or as a suction directed away from the surface, IW, q, Ct = as defined in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(1), Cei= exposure factor for internal pressure, as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(7), Cgi= internal gust effect factor, as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.3.(10), and Cpi= internal pressure coefficient, as provided in Article 4.1.7.7.

National Sentence Text: The reference velocity pressure, q, shall be the appropriate value determined in conformance with Subsection 1.1.3., based on a probability of being exceeded in any one year of 1 in 50.
P/T Sentence Text: The reference velocity pressure, q, shall be the appropriate value determined in conformance with part 1., based on a probability of being exceeded in any one year of 1 in 50.

National Sentence Text: The exposure factor, Ce, shall be based on the reference height, h, determined in accordance with Sentence 4.1.7.3.(6), for the surface or part of the surface under consideration and shall be (h/10)0.2 but not less than 0.9 for open terrain, where open terrain is level terrain with only scattered buildings, trees or other obstructions, open water or shorelines thereof, 0.7(h/12)0.3 but not less than 0.7 for rough terrain, where rough terrain is suburban, urban or wooded terrain extending upwind from the building uninterrupted for at least 1 km or 20 times the height of the building, whichever is greater, or an intermediate value between the two exposures defined in Clauses 4.1.7.3.(5)(a)and 4.1.7.3.(5)(b) in cases where the site is less than 1 km or 20 times the height of the building from a change in terrain conditions, whichever is greater, provided an appropriate interpolation method is used (see Note A-4.1.7.3.(5)(c)).
P/T Sentence Text: The exposure factor, Ce, shall be based on the reference height, h, determined in accordance with Sentence 4.1.7.3.(6), for the surface or part of the surface under consideration and shall be (h/10)0.2 but not less than 0.9 for open terrain, where open terrain is level terrain with only scattered buildings, trees or other obstructions, open water or shorelines thereof, 0.7(h/12)0.3 but not less than 0.7 for rough terrain, where rough terrain is suburban, urban or wooded terrain extending upwind from the building uninterrupted for at least 1 km or 20 times the height of the building, whichever is greater, or an intermediate value between the two exposures defined in Clauses 4.1.7.3.(5)and 4.1.7.3.(5) in cases where the site is less than 1 km or 20 times the height of the building from a change in terrain conditions, whichever is greater, provided an appropriate interpolation method is used (see Note A-4.1.7.3.(5)(c)).

National Sentence Text: The reference height, h, shall be determined as follows: for buildings whose height is less than or equal to 20 m and less than the smaller plan dimension, h shall be the mid-height of the roof above grade, but not less than 6 m, for other buildings, h shall be the actual height above grade of the point on the windward wall for which external pressures are being calculated, the mid-height of the roof for pressures on surfaces parallel to the wind direction, and the mid-height of the building for pressures on the leeward wall, and for any structural element exposed to wind, h shall be the mid-height of the element above the ground.
P/T Sentence Text: The reference height, h, shall be determined as follows: for buildings whose height is less than or equal to 20 m and less than the smaller plan dimension, h shall be the mid-height of the roof above grade, but not less than 6 m, for other buildings, h shall be the actual height above grade of the point on the windward wall for which external pressures are being calculated, the mid-height of the roof for pressures on surfaces parallel to the wind direction, and the mid-height of the building for pressures on the leeward wall, and for any structural element exposed to wind, h shall be the mid-height of the element above the ground.

National Sentence Text: The exposure factor for internal pressures, Cei, shall be determined as follows: for buildings whose height is greater than 20 m and that have a dominant opening, Cei shall be equal to the exposure factor for external pressures, Ce, calculated at the mid-height of the dominant opening, and for other buildings, Cei shall be the same as the exposure factor for external pressures, Ce, calculated for a reference height, h, equal to the mid-height of the building or 6 m, whichever is greater.
P/T Sentence Text: The exposure factor for internal pressures, Cei, shall be determined as follows: for buildings whose height is greater than 20 m and that have a dominant opening, Cei shall be equal to the exposure factor for external pressures, Ce, calculated at the mid-height of the dominant opening, and for other buildings, Cei shall be the same as the exposure factor for external pressures, Ce, calculated for a reference height, h, equal to the mid-height of the building or 6 m, whichever is greater.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 4.1.7.3.(9)and 4.1.7.6.(1), the gust effect factor, Cg, shall be one of the following values: 2.0 for the building as a whole and main structural members, or 2.5 for external pressures and suctions on secondary structural members, including cladding.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentences 4.1.7.3.(9) and 4.1.7.6.(1), the gust effect factor, Cg, shall be one of the following values: 2.0 for the building as a whole and main structural members, or 2.5 for external pressures and suctions on secondary structural members, including cladding.

National Sentence Text: For cases where Cg and Cp are combined into a single product, CpCg, the values of Cp and Cg need not be independently specified. (See Article 4.1.7.6.)
P/T Sentence Text: For cases where Cg and Cp are combined into a single product, CpCg, the values of Cp and Cg need not be independently specified. (See Article 4.1.7.6.)

National Sentence Text: The internal gust effect factor, Cgi, shall be 2.0, except it is permitted to be calculated using the following equation for large structures enclosing a single large unpartitioned volume that does not have numerous overhead doors or openings: Cgi=1+11+V06950AwhereV0= internal volume, in m3, and A= total area of all exterior openings of the volume, in m2. (See Note A-4.1.7.3.(10).)
P/T Sentence Text: The internal gust effect factor, Cgi, shall be 2.0, except it is permitted to be calculated using the following equation for large structures enclosing a single large unpartitioned volume that does not have numerous overhead doors or openings: Cgi=1+11+V06950AwhereV0= internal volume, in m3, and A= total area of all exterior openings of the volume, in m2.

National Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.4.(2), the topographic factor, Ct, shall be taken as 1.0.
P/T Sentence Text: Except as provided in Sentence 4.1.7.4.(2), the topographic factor, Ct, shall be taken as 1.0.

National Sentence Text: For buildings on hills or escarpments with a slope, Hh/(2Lh), greater than 0.1 (see Figure 4.1.7.4.), the topographic factor, Ct, shall be calculated as follows: Ct=1+DSCg1+DSwhere DS=DSmax1- xkLh exp-az/Lhwhere Smax= applicable value from Table 4.1.7.4., x= horizontal distance from the peak of the hill or escarpment, Lh= horizontal distance upwind from the peak to the point where the ground surface lies at half the height of the hill or escarpment, or 2Hh (where Hh = height of hill or escarpment), whichever is greater, z= height above ground, and k and  = applicable constants from Table 4.1.7.4. based on shape of hill or escarpment.
P/T Sentence Text: For buildings on hills or escarpments with a slope, Hh/(2Lh), greater than 0.1 (see Article 4.1.7.4.), the topographic factor, Ct, shall be calculated as follows: Ct=1+DSCg1+DSwhere DS=DSmax1- xkLh exp-az/Lhwhere Smax= applicable value from Table 4.1.7.4., x= horizontal distance from the peak of the hill or escarpment, Lh= horizontal distance upwind from the peak to the point where the ground surface lies at half the height of the hill or escarpment, or 2Hh (where Hh = height of hill or escarpment), whichever is greater, z= height above ground, and k and  = applicable constants from Table 4.1.7.4. based on shape of hill or escarpment.

National Sentence Text: Applicable values of external pressure coefficients, Cp, are provided in Sentences 4.1.7.5.(2)to 4.1.7.5.(5), and Article 4.1.7.6. for certain shapes of low buildings.
P/T Sentence Text: Applicable values of external pressure coefficients, Cp, are provided in Sentences 4.1.7.5.(2) to 4.1.7.5.(5), and Article 4.1.7.6. for certain shapes of low buildings.

National Sentence Text: For the design of the main structural system, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where H is the height of the building and D is the width of the building parallel to the wind direction: on the windward face,Cp= 0.6 for H/D < 0.25 = 0.27(H/D + for 0.25   H/D < 1.0, and = 0.8 for H/D   1.0, on the leeward face,Cp= –0.3 for H/D < 0.25, = –0.27(H/D + 0.88) for 0.25   H/D < 1.0, and = –0.5 for H/D   1.0, and on the walls parallel to the wind, Cp = –0.7. (See Note A-4.1.7.5.(2) and (3).)
P/T Sentence Text: For the design of the main structural system, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where H is the height of the building and D is the width of the building parallel to the wind direction: on the windward face,Cp= 0.6 for H/D < 0.25 = 0.27(H/D + for 0.25   H/D < 1.0, and = 0.8 for H/D   1.0, on the leeward face,Cp= –0.3 for H/D < 0.25, = –0.27(H/D + 0.88) for 0.25   H/D < 1.0, and = –0.5 for H/D   1.0, and on the walls parallel to the wind, Cp = –0.7.

National Sentence Text: For the design of roofs, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where x is the distance from the upwind edge of the roof: for H/D   1.0, Cp = –1.0, and for H/D < 1.0,Cp= –1.0 for x   H, and = –0.5 for x > H. (See Note A-4.1.7.5.(2) and (3).)
P/T Sentence Text: For the design of roofs, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where x is the distance from the upwind edge of the roof: for H/D   1.0, Cp = –1.0, and for H/D < 1.0,Cp= –1.0 for x   H, and = –0.5 for x > H.

National Sentence Text: For the design of the cladding and of secondary structural elements supporting the cladding, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where W and D are the widths of the building: on walls, Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1D and 0.1W from a building corner, the negative value of Cp shall be taken as –1.2, on walls where vertical ribs deeper than 1 m are placed on the facade, Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that, within a distance equal to the larger of 0.2D and 0.2W from a building corner, the negative value of Cp shall be taken as –1.4, and on roofs, Cp shall be taken as –1.0, except that within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1D and 0.1W from a roof edge, Cp shall be taken as –1.5, in a zone that is within a distance equal to the larger of 0.2W and 0.2D from a roof corner, Cp shall be taken as –2.3 but is permitted to be taken as –2.0 for roofs with perimeter parapets that are higher than 1 m, and on lower levels of flat stepped roofs, positive pressure coefficients established for the walls of the steps apply for a distance b (see Figure 4.1.7.6. for the definition of b). (See Note A-4.1.7.5.(4).)
P/T Sentence Text: For the design of the cladding and of secondary structural elements supporting the cladding, the value of Cp shall be established as follows, where W and D are the widths of the building: on walls, Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1D and 0.1W from a building corner, the negative value of Cp shall be taken as –1.2, on walls where vertical ribs deeper than 1 m are placed on the facade, Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that, within a distance equal to the larger of 0.2D and 0.2W from a building corner, the negative value of Cp shall be taken as –1.4, and on roofs, Cp shall be taken as –1.0, except that within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1D and 0.1W from a roof edge, Cp shall be taken as –1.5, in a zone that is within a distance equal to the larger of 0.2W and 0.2D from a roof corner, Cp shall be taken as –2.3 but is permitted to be taken as –2.0 for roofs with perimeter parapets that are higher than 1 m, and on lower levels of flat stepped roofs, positive pressure coefficients established for the walls of the steps apply for a distance b (see Article 4.1.7.6. for the definition of b).

National Sentence Text: For the design of balcony guards, the internal pressure coefficient, Cpi, shall be taken as zero and the value of Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1W and 0.1D from a building corner, Cp shall be taken as ±1.2.
P/T Sentence Text: For the design of balcony guards, the internal pressure coefficient, Cpi, shall be taken as zero and the value of Cp shall be taken as ±0.9, except that within a distance equal to the larger of 0.1W and 0.1D from a building corner, Cp shall be taken as ±1.2.

National Sentence Text: For the design of buildings with a height, H, that is both less than or equal to 20 m and less than the smaller plan dimension, the values of the product of the pressure coefficient and gust factor, CpCg, provided in Sentences 4.1.7.6.(2)to 4.1.7.6.(9) are permitted to be used.

National Sentence Text: For the design of the main structural system of the building, which is affected by wind pressures on more than one surface, the values of CpCg are provided in Figure 4.1.7.6..

National Sentence Text: For the design of roofs with a slope less than or equal to 7°, the values of CpCg are provided in Figure 4.1.7.6..

National Sentence Text: The internal pressure coefficient, Cpi, shall be as prescribed in Table 4.1.7.7.
P/T Sentence Text: The internal pressure coefficient, Cpi, shall be as prescribed in Table 4.1.7.7.

National Sentence Text: For the application of the Dynamic Procedure, the provisions of Article 4.1.7.3. shall be followed, except that the exposure factor, Ce, shall be as prescribed in Sentences 4.1.7.8.(2)and 4.1.7.8.(3), and the gust effect factor, Cg, shall be as prescribed in Sentence 4.1.7.8.(4), when determining the wind loads on the main structural system.

(See Note A-4.1.7.8.(4).)
